div.head: ROUSE HIS CASE, Truly Stated and Written with his own Hand in Newgate, Two days before his Execution, to prevent any fal≈øe Reports, &c.
div.p:
WEdne≈øday, July 4. 83. Towards Evening I went into Barbican to ≈øpeak with a Friend, I went into a Coffee-hou≈øe, drank a Mugg of Ale, of a ≈øuddain I heard a noi≈øe of Swordmen that were coming to ≈øearch the ≈øaid Hou≈øe for a per≈øon called Armiger; I being alone in a low. Room, walked into the Garden until ≈øuch time as the hurry ≈øhould be over; while I was in the Garden, out comes one Man, then another, ≈øeeing me, asked if my Name was not Armiger? I replyed and ≈øaid, no. What is your Name then ≈øaid one of the per≈øons? Now I was altogether ignorant of what they meant, Note, that they had no Warrant again≈øt me. or that they had any Warrant from White-hall to impower one or both as a Me≈ø≈øenger or Me≈ø≈øengers, and therefore made this An≈øwer, John-Son, being the Son of John.
Note, That if I had been guilty of any Plot, I ≈øhould not have been upon the Exchange to the la≈øt, and about my own bu≈øine≈øs every day. But one of them, called William Richard≈øon, being a Me≈ø≈øenger, having a General Warrant to que≈øtion and take up all that he ≈øu≈øpected, demanded the place of my aboad, to ≈øee whether I were ≈øuch a per≈øon: Thereupon I made an Apollogy for my ≈øelf, and told them my Name was Rou≈øe; Thereupon a Porter was ≈øent to my Hou≈øe, and about the Neighborhood, to ≈øatisfie them≈øelves that
≈øuch a one lived there; that would not ≈øatisfie, but they would have ≈øome known per≈øon ‚Ä¢ thereabout to ‚Ä¢ ngage for me; whe ‚Ä¢ upon I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nt, and ≈øome where not a ‚Ä¢ home, others were ≈øhy of Appearing, and when they ≈øaw that, nothing mu≈øt ≈øerve, but they charged a Con≈øtable with me, took Coach and carried me to the Fleet for ≈øecurity, the Secre ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ry of the ≈øame being an a≈ø≈øi≈øtant to the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øenge. This was about Ten or Eleven at Night‚ñ™

Next ‚Ä¢ orning I was carried ‚Ä¢ o White-hall,
Thur≈øday, 5. day. after a little while I was called into the Secretary's Chamber, where were pre≈øent, the King, the Duke of York, Lord Keeper North, Lord Hallifax, Lord Sunderland, Secretary, Secretary Jenkins; Lord Keeper acquainted me that there was an Information brought again≈øt me of Trea≈øon, and in≈øtanced in ≈øeveral particulars. However, if I would be ingenuous, and confe≈øs the per≈øons concerned, or knew of any thing again≈øt His Maje≈øty, I ≈øhould find favour. Thereupon I de≈øired to be excu≈øed from an≈øwering then, (to prevent any mi≈øtakes, ≈øeeing ≈øo many at the Table with each Man his Pen ready to write down whatever was ≈øpoken) but promi≈øed to put into writing what I knew of any de≈øign again≈øt His Maje≈øty, or the Peace of His Kingdom; which when they heard, the Duke of York urged with divers Arguments to ≈øpeak what I had to ≈øay immediately; but I ≈øtill in≈øi≈øted upon Writing my Mind: Thereupon His Maje≈øty propo≈øed, and it was agreed on, that I ≈øhould take Four or Five hours, and be alone, to do what was nece≈ø≈øary, and the Me≈ø≈øenger was ordered to carry me to the Plantation-Office near Scotland Yard, where a Guard was ≈øet till I had fini≈øhed. About Four in the Afternoon I went with my Paper, and one of the Clerks of the Council was ordred to receive it, who calling for it, carried it in, and I was ordered to tarry a while; mean time Mr. Thomas Lee a Dyer was called in, who was the per≈øon that Informed again≈øt me, and who him≈øelf was Sworn
again≈øt by two others, viz. How of Old-≈øtreet, and Keeling of Ea≈øt-Smithfield: when he came out, I was called in and the Lord Keeper told me, I had not been free and ingenuous, but did keep back what was material, having received further Information again≈øt me; upon which I told them, that I had done what po≈ø≈øible could be done within that ≈øpace of time allotted, and promi≈øed whatever ≈øhould accrue to my memory I would faithfully di≈øcover, and not fal≈øly accu≈øe either Friend or Foe: Then I was ordered to withdraw, and ordered to appear next day by Eight in the Morning; then I return'd to the Fleet again. And

I was carried up again, tarried all the Forenoon,
Fryday, 6. day. not called in, but adjourned till Four the ≈øame day; at Four a Clock, having Dined at Temple-Barr, went up again, and was adjourned till Four a Clock next day; ≈øo went to the Fleet again.

About Seven or Eight at Night I was ≈øent away by Water with a File of Soldiers to the Mar≈øhal≈øey, where I were committed clo≈øe Pri≈øoner, next day put in Chains, and could not have the liberty of any one to acquaint my Wife where I was, though I begged as for an Alms, and told the Mar≈øhal how my Wife was big and near her time.

The Mar≈øhal received an order to bring me to Whitehall,
Tu≈øeday, 10. where we went, tarried ≈øome Hours, and ordered to appear next Morning.

In≈øtead of going to White-hall,
Wedne≈øday, 11. an Habias Corpus was ≈øent to carry me to Newgate. About Nine in the Forenoon I was carried to Newgate, where my Wife came to me and tarried about half an hour, but could get no other Friend till Nine at Night, nor Council to advi≈øe withal without Order of Court.

Captain Richard≈øon carried me to the Old-Baley,
Thur≈øday, 12. and being there, I found that Captain Blage and my ≈øelf were put in one Indictment, which was read, to which we pleaded Not Guilty. Then we withdrew; the Bill given to the Grand Inque≈øt, who found it again≈øt us both; afterwards being called again, to hold up our Hands, we Pleaded as before: Being asked by whom we would be Tryed, we an≈øwered, By God and our Countrey.

Fryday 13. We were called again, and required to take our Tryal, Captain Blage asked, whether we mu≈øt An≈øwer, ≈øeverally or jointly, Sir George Jefferies ≈øaid, we might An≈øwer ≈øeverally, then the Captain Begged Liberty to An≈øwer for him≈øelf, ‚Ä¢ nd the Court Ordered me to take mine fir≈øt, but before I took my Tryal, I prayed the Court for more time, becau≈øe of the di≈øadvantages that I had been under, however the Court would not admit of it, but ≈øaid, I mu≈øt do it now, to which I ≈øubmitted, having no Copy of the Indictment, no Councel nor other to advi≈øe withal, the Indictment read, and Witne≈øs called in to prove it, which was, viz. Thomas Lea Dyer, William Leigh, Captain Blage's Mate, Thomas Corbin al≈øo brought, not as a Material Witne≈øs in this matter, as Sir George Jefferies declared, but to declare words that I ≈øhould ≈øpeak in 81, who≈øe Evidence could not be allowed then, becau≈øe Ju≈øtice could not be had, and at ≈øuch a time, when the Judge was in fear of his Life, as he ≈øate upon the Bench. Moreover, Sir George Jefferies ≈øaid, how that I were to be Pay-ma≈øter, under a great now dead to a Rabble, the fourth Witne≈øs was Richard≈øon, the Me≈ø≈øenger to Witne≈øs where he took me, and how I ≈øpoke of John≈øon.

The Witne≈ø≈øes being Sworn, the Indictment was read, how that I ≈øhould be Guilty as before, and particularly that on the ≈øecond of March la≈øt, I was with divers others at ≈øuch a place, where Captain William Blage, and had many Armes, as Blunderbu≈ø≈øes &c. and contrived as before, Lea Swears not a Word of this, but that on the la≈øt of June, we were at the Kings-head in Sweetings Alley London, that we contrived taking the Tower, of the City of London, Whitehall, St. James's, that Captain william Blage, his Mate, and other Sea-men were Ingaged in taking the Tower, how that a Golden Ball was to be thrown up upon Black-heath, for to Gather Sea-men together at the drinking of a Bowl of Punch, that the Aldermen were to be Kill'd, His Maje≈øty and Duke of York ≈øecured, but ≈øaid, the truth was Mr. Rou≈øe was not for Shedding of Blood; much le≈øs Killing of the KING and his Highne≈øs the DUKE of York, that Goodenough, and I Di≈øcour≈øed about it, and that Mr.
Goodenough did give him thanks for his Acquaintance with me, that it was contrived, His Maje≈øty was to be ≈øeized as he came from Wind≈øor, that Armes were to be ≈øent down in Trunks, that all was to be done before Mid Summer, being asked, who began any Di≈øcour≈øe of this Nature, whether he or I fir≈øt, indeed that he could not well remember, the price of the Ball was valued by me at 10 s.telling of R. Goodenough of it, he ≈øhould ≈øay, no matter if it co≈øt 40 s. we will have it, farther he ≈øwears, that I ≈øhould ≈øay that the King had Sworn in Spain √® France, to e≈øtabli≈øh Popery in England, and for not performing his Oath the Papi≈øts were angry with him; upon all which, Sir George Jefferies animadverted, and aggrivated as much as po≈ø≈øible.

2. Witne≈øs, was William Leigh, who was Informed again≈øt by Lea, as a Confederate with William Blage, in contriving how to take the Tower, this Witne≈øs now was brought, that they might have full Evidence to Swear again≈øt me, he threw that upon me, which he was in≈øtigated and prompted too by Lea.
3. Witne≈øs, Corbin, who Swore that I ≈øhould ≈øay in 81. that His Maje≈øty had forfeited his Crown, that he had no more, but what a Parliament could give or take away when they plea≈øed.

4. Witne≈øs, Richard≈øon ≈øo prov'd the word John≈øon, whereupon, Sir George Jefferies took occa≈øion to ≈øignifie, what Spirit the Pri≈øoner was of always again≈øt the King, that I had as many names as de≈øigns.

To all which I replied, viz. fir≈øt, as to Lea, how he was but of late acquaintance, being as I well remember about May, ≈øo that of the ≈øecond of March, mu≈øt fall to ground, that when he entred into a Di≈øcour≈øe with me once, and again it was about a Forraign Inva≈øion, to oppo≈øe which I di≈øcovered my tenderne≈øs again and again, that what was di≈øcour≈øed about the Tower and Sea-men, the Captain and others, was by and from him≈øelf, as I find he di≈øcour≈øed with
Mr. Hone, and Mr. Keeling formerly, that another, I, nor Captain Blage did look on it for a great while, but Romantick Di≈øcour≈øe; that it was never in my heart in the lea≈øt to appear again≈øt His Maje≈øty, or do any thing again≈øt the Peace of his Government.

That Lea had been an Indu≈øtrious drudge, to carry on a De≈øign, and to ≈øee how it would take, that it was his cunning to ≈øpeak with but one very rarely at a time, ≈øave Captain William Blage, and his Mate was pre≈øent and no other, that there was never a word, that ever pa≈øt about any ≈øuch things between Goodenough and I, that I never ≈øaw him but twice after ≈øuch Di≈øcour≈øe aro≈øe, and one of the times he asked me if I knew Captain Blage, that he ≈øaw he was a ≈øtout Fellow and hoped he was hone≈øt, I told him I knew no other and no more, but the Di≈øcour≈øe fell to the Ground that I never knew of any meeting with Captain Blage, that we were never together with him, that whatever it was, I found Lea carried it on upon a De≈øign to rai≈øe him≈øelf in the World.

That I never ≈øpoke what Corbin ≈øwore too ≈øingly and barely, but as that may be hereafter, that the Mate was under a ≈øurprize as to ≈øome things, but that I asked him if he were acquainted with hone≈øt Hone. I deny not, but not upon any account of a De≈øign again≈øt His Maje≈øty. That when I ≈øaid John≈øon, I had no knowledge of the Per≈øons or there asking my name, nor that was a denying of my name, being asked for Witne≈ø≈øes, let the World Judge in what capacity I were to produce any, and for what, that what civillity I ≈øhewed Lea, was no manner of Argument that I de≈øigned Injury to my King, that I was often afraid of his going away, or that he would be under a Temptation, to do by me, as he oft threatned to do by Keeling, and Harry very often told me, that he was never in that Rogues Company but once in four Months, that he had been at Ea≈øt-Smithfield on purpo≈øe to Kill that Dog.

That Lea being taken up, and being concious to him≈øelf, what he had ≈øaid, was Guilty of, and how he was in with
Nelthrop &c. who Ob≈øconded that I had heard him, ≈øpeak very unworthily of, and again≈øt the Duke of York, that he was privy to ≈øome Wicked De≈øign or other, now for fear I ≈øhould appear again≈øt him, the Devil put him upon Swearing that again≈øt me, whereof he knows in his own Con≈øcience he was the Sole Author, but God forgive him, and grant my Blood may not be laid to his Charge, then I withdrew, and the Jury brought me in Guilty of High Trea≈øon, again≈øt whom I have nothing to ≈øay, they are to give Account at a Greater Bar, if Guilty of any Error, and be≈øides, I ever had a great Veneration for that Con≈øtitution, however, ≈øome Euthorigant Licentious Per≈øons take Liberty to be≈øpatter that Kind of Order.
Next Captain Blage was called, and but one Witne≈øs again≈øt him, he was acquitted.

Saturday the Fourteenth, Captain Thomas Walcot, a Man I never knew, William Hone and I were called to the Bar, where each of us read our Sentence of Death, not to ≈øpeak of the Defence I made them, for it was over-ruled, now after all that has been ≈øaid Pro and Con, It concerns me as a Man, an Engli≈øh-man and Chri≈øtian, for the ≈øatisfaction of all Per≈øons to whom this Story ≈øhall come, having a clear Con≈øcience, as to any De≈øign again≈øt the King or Government, ≈øave that I heard ≈øuch di≈øcour≈øe, that I could not heartily acquies in.
I do declare ≈øolemnly, in the Words of a dying Man, being under the Sentence of Death, and as I know to whom I mu≈øt give Account for the ≈øame.

That I ever declared again≈øt King Killing Principles and Practices, but rather looked on it as my duty, and made it my Practice to Pray for him, as often as I Prayed for dayly bread or for my own Soul.

That I never knew none of the Per≈øons in the Pr ‚Ä¢ clamation, until the fir≈øt Pr ‚Ä¢ clamation after, Collon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Flem≈øey See. That I was never to be a Pay-ma≈øter to any ‚Ä¢ abble under agreement to the Lord now dead, and Sir George Je≈ø≈øerres ≈øaid, I were but only a Pay ma≈øter in Flanders 78. for Lea mu≈øt needs know, and then he could ≈øay, that they were all concerned, and many go up and down England, if ≈øo the more Wicked Wretch he to Conceal it ≈øo long, and for being ≈øo ≈øh ‚Ä¢ , ‚Ä¢ otwith≈øtanding all my ≈øiftings of him to know, but as I ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ id he had a Wicked De≈øign to carry on, and ≈øo he might e≈øcape at la≈øt, he did not care again≈øt whom he ≈øwore, for there are more be≈øides my ≈øelf.

That I never knew of any Armes, as Blunderbu≈ø≈øes, &c. provided or to be provided, That I never ≈øpoke to any Se ‚Ä¢
men, about carrying on a De≈øign, ≈øave a kind of di≈øcour≈øe, which Lea fomented and promoted in the pre≈øence of Captain William Blage, and his Mate, with whom I was as an old acquaintance, acquainted for many Years, and whom I knew to be Faithful to his Prince, whom he had ≈øerved for many years at Sea, with his life, whom I a≈ø≈øi≈øted for his di≈øpatch to New-York, and knew his re≈øolution, and bent lay that way, for which place he bought a Ship, and was making all manner of ha≈øt to be gone.

That I never knew of any de≈øign again≈øt the City, or much le≈øs Killing the Aldermen, that I never knew of Attaching His Maje≈øty (whom God pre≈øerve) as he ≈øhould come from Wind≈øor or any place el≈øe, that I never heard one word from Richard Gondenough, of acting any ≈øuch thing or any other, that I had been acquainted with Richard Goodenough many Years, as an Attorney and no otherwi≈øe, and therefore it was unlikely that he ≈øhould give Iea thanks for bringing him to his acquaintance, that the≈øe were none of my words, I never did or could ≈øay, that His Maje≈øty had taken an Oa ‚Ä¢ h in Spain „Äà‚óä„Äâ France to do ≈øo and ≈øo, and that I ≈øhould have it under the Kings hand, I utterly deny it, but I remember I heard a profligate Villain ≈øpeak ≈øomewhat to that purpo≈øe, this was ≈øome Years pa≈øt, and I might ≈øpeak what a Villain
that was he that ≈øpoke after that rate, that what was ≈øpoke by the Mate, and about his An≈øwer, ob≈øerving with him≈øelf the ≈ølightne≈øs of many places about the Tower, which made him ≈øay any Man might take it with Four or Five Hundred Men, if they had ≈øuch a mind, and Provi≈øion accordingly, that it was only for di≈øcour≈øe ≈øake, without any premeditated De≈øign.

That what Corbin ≈øaid about the Crown, was enquired into
„Äà‚óä„Äâ France by a former Jury not to hold water, that when one of the Company Wyat, was ≈øpeaking of the Power of the Power of Popes over Kings, &c. I replyed again, that if that were ≈øo, that the Pope could depo≈øe Kings at plea≈øure, and di≈øpo≈øe there Crowns to others, (which I oppo≈øed and denied) that then he might give it to me or any other, and by that Doctrine, I might or any other there Challenge it, ≈øo that Corbin dealt by me as a Je≈øuited Evidence, who hearing a Mini≈øter Preach upon that, in P≈øalm the Fourteenth ver≈øe the fir≈øt, the Fool hath ≈øaid in his Heart, there is no God; he goes and ≈øwears that the Man ≈øpake Bla≈øphemy, ≈øaying, there is no God, leaving out the former Words, which being joyned are hone≈øt and good, and if Corbin had been ≈øo hone≈øt, as to ≈øpeak all what I ≈øaid, my words could no more have been Trea≈øon and Di≈øloyal; then the Mini≈øters words Bla≈øphemous, but I am bound to pray God to forgive my Enemies, not only ≈øeven but ≈øeventy times ≈øeven, and God forgive them all (tho never ≈øo Implacable) as I am taught to pray that God would forgive me my Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes.

That I declare my Abhorrence of ≈øuch De≈øigns and Practi≈øes, as have brought an Odium upon the Prote≈øtant Religion, let Men pretend to what they will, I am ≈øure they could be none that either Fear God, or Honor the King; if any blame me for knowing any thing of it, and did not immediatly di≈øcover it, I mu≈øt An≈øwer, that my De≈øign was good, and I were loath to carry a piece, or a broken Story, as I told His Maje≈øty, or el≈øe he had heard it ≈øooner, and that Lea was well advi≈øed of, and my di≈øcharging him from my Hou≈øe, gave no ≈ømall Jealou≈øie among other things. This being the Summ and Sub≈øtance what I have to ≈øay, I now conclude, in owning my ≈øelf (whatever
others ≈øay or think) to dye in the belief of the Doctrin, of that part of Chri≈øts Church planted in England, being agreeable to the Doctrine of the Prophets and Apo≈øtles, Chri≈øt Je≈øus being the Chief Corner Stone, praying God to ha≈øten the calling of the Jews, To bring in the Gentiles, de≈øtroy Babylon, build up Sion, pre≈øerve Great Brittain, e≈øpecially His Maje≈øtles Per≈øon and Government, that Peace with Truth may Flouri≈øh, Ble≈øs and provide for my dear Yoak-Fellow and little ones, with all my Relations; pre≈øerve London and We≈øtmin≈øter, order and over-rule all publick and private Tran≈øactions, to his Glory, and ha≈øten his coming the ≈øecond time.

La≈øtly, I Commit my Body to the Care of my Friends by His Maje≈øties leave, for a decent Burial, Believing a Re≈øurrection, and my Soul to that God who≈øe right it is: But this would not be granted the Petitioned for,

div.head: A Letter, Written to his WIFE out of Newgate.
div.p:
WHen God brought us fir≈øt together, we made full Account of parting one time or other, but who≈øe Lot ≈øhould be fir≈øt, or the manner of our parting, and death, that was Locked up in Gods Cabinet, and now after Fourteen Years cohabitation we mu≈øt part, it's true, were it at our own Hou≈øe, and by an u≈øual ordinary common way, we ≈øhould be better plea≈øed it may be, but this is the way appointed, my Sins have been the procuring, though Evil Men the In≈øtrumental Cau≈øe. This we know, it is appointed to all Men once to dye, and after that the Judgment, it is now my Lot to be called away, not by an ordinary, but extraordinary, Violent Shameful way of dying, but what of all that? May God being reconciled to me through Chri≈øt, the Hand-writing Concealed, Sins Pardoned, Nature Sanctifyed, Soul Wa≈øhed in the Blood of Sprinkling, Con≈øcience Excu≈øing not Accu≈øing, as to that Crime Charged on me, though I have received Sentence from the Judgment Seat of Man, I ≈øhall be acquitted at the Judgment Seat of God, having this Confidence, the manner of dying, accompanyed with ≈øuch outward Ignominy and Reproach, and ≈øo many Hundred Spectators, ≈øome to Triumph, others to plea≈øe fancy, and a few out of true Love and Sympathy, I ≈øay in this Confidence, I am highly unconcern'd, it is but a few hours, and this Noi≈øe, Rout and Vanity will be over. What ≈øhall Indians that Dream of a place (after death) full of Carnal plea≈øure, ≈øhall Papi≈øts upon Account of their Merits, and an Ab≈øolution at Death, indure any kind of torture, and ≈øhall I

Now I bid thee adieu, till we meet where all Signs and Tears ≈øhall be wiped away; but before we part, I am under all Obligations imaginable, to leave thee that I can to ≈øupport thee, ≈øince I have left thee in ≈øuch a condition, as (without a great mea≈øure of Strength and Grace) the thoughts thereof would quite ≈øink thy Spirit: But chear up from the≈øe Con≈øiderations, What though my Husband be dead and gone, yet I have a tender, loving, good Father alive on Earth, and which is more, I have a greater and far better Father in Heaven. What though I am a Widow, and have many Fatherle≈øs Children to take care of and provide for; what then? have I not a God who hath ≈øtiled him≈øelf the Father of the Fatherle≈øs, and a Husband to the Widdow in his holy Habitation? When at any time you think of your Husband and manner of his death, endeavour to fetch Honey out of the Lyons Carka≈øs; bani≈øh away all hard thoughts of God, who hath done us no wrong; though this Providence ≈øeems har≈øh and ≈øevere to us, yet it is Ju≈øt and Righteous in our Lord, Even that God that cha≈øti≈øeth the Heathen, ≈øhall not he correct? I know that thoughts, and many trouble≈øome and ≈øolicitous ones, will now and then ari≈øe, and work ≈øtrangely; Con≈øider it was thus with Holy David: Then in the multitude of thy thoughts within thee, let Gods Comforts delight thy Soul. div.head: Here follows his Advice to his Children.

my Prayers for you are, that as you are mine by natural Generation, That God would make you his by the Grace of Adoption, that when your Earthly Father ≈øhall leave you, the Father of Spirits may take care and provide for you; though you and every of you be Children of Wrath by Nature, you may never be Subjects of Wrath; though you live in the World, you may be kept from the evil of the World; and la≈øtly, when you leave this World, you may have a Hou≈øe, not made with hands, Eternal in the Heavens.
